items.title: LxmlDriver-based backends do not support the new FindLinks API
items.body:
<details>
<summary>Original Comment</summary>
I have a simple solution (locally subclassed) for our own test suite

```python
class LxmlFindLinks:
    def __init__(self, parent):
        self.parent = parent

    def find_by_href(self, href):
        return self.parent.find_by_xpath('//a[@href="{}"]'.format(href))

    def find_by_partial_href(self, partial_href):
        return self.parent.find_by_xpath('//a[contains(@href, "{}")]'.format(partial_href))

    def find_by_partial_text(self, partial_text):
        return self.parent.find_by_xpath('//a[contains(normalize-space(.), "{}")]'.format(partial_text))

    def find_by_text(self, text):
        return self.parent.find_by_xpath('//a[text()="{}"]'.format(text))

class FlaskClient(_FlaskClient):
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        super().__init__(*args, **kwargs)
        self.links = LxmlFindLinks(self)
```

The other solution I could see would be to add support for either unknown kwargs to the LxmlDriver `find_by_xpath(selector, **_kwargs)`, or perhaps explicitly `find_by_xpath(selector, original_find=None, original_query=None)` and then using the same `FindLinks` class the Webdriver uses.
</details>

I saw how simple this actually is, and I'm submitting a PR to fix it

items.title: Firefox does not open in fullscreen mode when passing the according keyword argument
items.body:
The `fullscreen=True` argument to the Firefox browser constructor does not open the browser in full screen but in a regular non-maximized window instead:
```
from splinter import Browser

browser = Browser('firefox', fullscreen=True)
browser.visit('https://www.github.com')
```
Apart from that there is no error message.

For Chrome, however, it works just fine:
```
from splinter import Browser

browser = Browser('chrome', fullscreen=True)
browser.visit('https://www.github.com')
```

Versions:
* Ubuntu 18.04
* splinter 0.13.0
* selenium 3.141.0
* Firefox 73.0

items.title: splinter.driver.webdriver.WebDriverElement.screenshot: "'WebDriverElement' object has no attribute "recover_screen""
items.body:
When using screenshot function under splinter.driver.webdriver.WebDriverElement I get the following error: 

'''

        def screenshot(self, name='', suffix=".png", full=False):
            name = name or ''
            (fd, filename) = tempfile.mkstemp(prefix=name, suffix=suffix)
            # don't hold the file
            os.close(fd)
    
            if full:
                self.parent.full_screen()
            target = self.screenshot_as_png()
           > self.parent.recover_screen()
           E       AttributeError: 'WebDriverElement' object has no attribute "recover_screen"
'''

I believe it's because of the refactored function "_find" in .../Webdriver/init.py. When WebDriverElement calls the "_find" function, it instantiates the object using "self" on line 254 



    def _find(self, finder, selector):
  
         [...]

        if elements:
            elem_list = [self.element_class(element, self) for element in elements]

        return elem_list


and self, type WebDriverElement, is passed to become the parent of that element. And that's when the error occurs because the screenshot function expects self.parent to be of type WebDriver that has 'recover_screen' function.

This was working before because parent was always type "WebDriver". This can be seen in find_by methods in WebDriverElement. For example, looking at older code (ver 11), you can see that 'WebDriverElement.find_by_xpath' passes the parent instead of self to instantiate.


    def find_by_xpath(self, selector, original_find=None, original_query=None):
        elements = ElementList(self._element.find_elements_by_xpath(selector))
        return ElementList(
            [self.__class__(element, self.parent) for element in elements],
            find_by="xpath",
            query=selector,
        )

Quick solution is to pass the parent instead of self in "_find" function when self is of type WebDriverElement but I do not know the code enough and may cause more issues.

Another possible solution is to implement the the missing functions that was expected for "WebDriver" such as  "recover_screen", "full_screen" for WebDriverElement class.

Let me know if any of the solution above is good and I'll create a pull request for it.

items.title: Unable to slice on ElementList in python3
items.body:
# Issue
Applying a type(slice) to an ElementList causes a `TypeError: Object of type slice is not JSON serializable`

This happens because of the __getitem__ implantation

``` python
py3/lib/python3.7/site-packages/splinter/element_list.py
def __getitem__(self, index):
    if not isinstance(index, int):
        return self.first[index]
    ...
```

Slicing in python 3 will cause index to be type(slice). So when ` if not isinstance(index, int)`
get's evaluated, the code will return `return self.first[index]`.

However this is incorrect. We want to slice(take a subset of the ElementList), but the code being execute will try and slice on the first item of the list.

Instead the code should handle type(slice) independently. Here's an example implementation...

``` python
def __getitem__(self, index):
    if isinstance(index, slice):
        # Handle none vales e.g. slice(None, 3, None) -> slice(0, 3, 1)
        return [
            self[i]
            for i in range(index.start or 0, index.stop or len(self), index.step or 1)
        ]
    ...
```

items.title: WebDriverElement. select* implicitly rely on presence of name attribute for selector
items.body:
#620 asked about using `select` (and by extension, `select_by_text`) for an element without a name

But if you check implementation for methods defined for `WebDriverElement`, both contain search by selector's `name`

https://github.com/cobrateam/splinter/blob/32f11ff7fd7841b123f157720dcc95740f156ca8/splinter/driver/webdriver/__init__.py#L616

https://github.com/cobrateam/splinter/blob/32f11ff7fd7841b123f157720dcc95740f156ca8/splinter/driver/webdriver/__init__.py#L621

I want to make a pull request for fixing this behavior, but I'm not sure which would be better:
- completely remove `name` from xpath 
- use xpath with `name` if `self["name"]` is not empty, otherwise, use xpath without `name`

items.title: ElementAPI.clear() shadows list.clear() in python 3.3+
items.body:
The following code in python <= 3.2 will call ElementAPI.clear():

```
browser.find_by_css('foobar').clear()
```

However, in python 3.3 and forward, the built-in list implements a clear() method. ElementList is a subclass of list, and as such the above code will call ElementList.clear().

The following still calls ElementAPI.clear() in all python versions:

```
browser.find_by_css('foobar').first.clear()
```

ElementList probably should not subclass list directly.

items.title: Django >= 2.0.6 now required for python > 3.3
items.body:
[This commit](https://github.com/cobrateam/splinter/commit/907208296d1936b2e8abfe21b7109cb0dad9e6a2) ([this part in particular](https://github.com/cobrateam/splinter/commit/907208296d1936b2e8abfe21b7109cb0dad9e6a2#diff-2eeaed663bd0d25b7e608891384b7298R30)) pins the django version to >= 2.0.6 if you're installing on python 3.3. As far as I know, Django 1.11 is still supported on python 3, and this dependency declaration prevents me from using django 1.11 with splinter if I want to be on python 3.3.

I think the correct thing to do here is just to declare a dependency on `django >= 1.7.11` regardless of the python version, since this library supports all django versions above that, and has little to do with the python version.

I can PR this if needed.
The place where this option should be added is:
[eggnita/splinter@d54fecf](https://github.com/eggnita/splinter/blob/d54fecf7ca95b3eb6814aad0eae14a5e44ef7591/splinter/driver/webdriver/chrome.py#L34)

items.title: DeprecationWarning: use options instead of chrome_options
items.body:
There is a deprecation warning that gets raised every time the Chrome backend is used. 

This is because `splinter/driver/webdriver/chrome.py` (line 35) uses `chrome_options` instead of `options`. It is literally a 7 character fix to use `options` instead, since this is what the underlying selenium code does.

items.title: _element should become part of the official API (allows Selenium calls)
items.body:
Let's look at some code similar to something I write using Splinter:

```
a = browser.find_by_id("foo")
txt = a._element.get_attribute('outerHTML')
try:
   txt.find('some HTML')
except:
   print("Test FAIL")
   return -1
```

The point being, I'm using _element to access a method in the underlying Selenium that Splinter does not appear to support.

We should make this part of the official API: If you want to do something with an element and Splinter does not support it, use _element to make the required Selenium call. This way, already written code does not need to be revised.

items.title: Firefox now support headless mode with environ variable
items.body:
Firefox support headless mode by setting MOZ_HEADLESS environ variable 

This code is showing how to do it at the moment (Tested with firefox 57 on windows)
```
import os
os.environ['MOZ_HEADLESS'] = '1'

with Timer(prefix="create browser"):
    browser = Browser('firefox')

with Timer(prefix="go to url"):
    url = "https://google.com"
    browser.visit(url)
```

maybe simply add Browser('firefox', headless=True) to set the environment variable?

reference: https://intoli.com/blog/running-selenium-with-headless-firefox/

Make fill_form search for a FORM tag and then search for all other elements from that element
items.body:
# The Problem

My web page has two items with `name == 'description'`

* `<meta name="description" content="">`
* `<textarea id="description" name="description" ng-model="product.description" class="ng-pristine ng-valid ng-scope form-control ng-empty ng-touched" style="">      </textarea>`

Using `fill_form` for this page fails because there are 2 possible elements where `name == 'description'`

```python
fill_form({'name': 'Fedora', 'label': 'fedora', 'description': 'Fedora Linux'})
```

# Error
```ipython
InvalidElementStateException: Message: invalid element state: Element is not currently interactable and may not be manipulated
```

Maybe the `fill_form` method should look for a `form` tag first, and assuming it finds it, try to fill out every one of its fields from this element?

items.title: Chrome --disable-gpu flag
items.body:
Currently running a headless Chrome tests on a server, including TravisCI servers, require passing `--disable-gpu` to `chrome` process.  Otherwise you get error "exit code 1" from Selenium. As far as I know there is no published schedule when `--disable-gpu` goes away as promised by Chrome development team.

I suggest adding a flag to `chrome_options` to control this besides `--headless`. 

I can champion a PR to get this added.

Example where this should be added:

https://github.com/websauna/splinter/commit/607ab7c4386a3f5d4edc3f3d96aa42aa94def812

items.title: StaleElementReferenceException from is_text_not_present
items.body:
I just encountered this stack trace (version 0.7.5):

```
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/splinter/driver/webdriver/__init__.py", line 319, in is_text_not_present
    self.driver.find_element_by_tag_name('body').text.index(text)
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 73, in text
    return self._execute(Command.GET_ELEMENT_TEXT)['value']
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webelement.py", line 491, in _execute
    return self._parent.execute(command, params)
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/webdriver.py", line 238, in execute
    self.error_handler.check_response(response)
  File "/.../lib/python3.6/site-packages/selenium/webdriver/remote/errorhandler.py", line 193, in check_response
    raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace)
selenium.common.exceptions.StaleElementReferenceException: Message: stale element reference: element is not attached to the page document
  (Session info: chrome=57.0.2987.133)
  (Driver info: chromedriver=2.27.440174 (e97a722caafc2d3a8b807ee115bfb307f7d2cfd9),platform=Mac OS X 10.11.6 x86_64)
```

It seems that the body went away after the call to `find_element_by_tag_name('body')` but before `text` could be accessed from the result. The possibility of this makes sense to me based on the application that I'm testing.

 I think the solution is to handle `StaleElementReferenceException` the same way as `NoSuchElementException`.

items.title: Expected browser binary location, but unable to find binary in default location
items.body:
With the Dockerfile:
```
FROM python:2.7-onbuild

RUN cd /usr/src/app
RUN mkdir /usr/src/app/drivers
RUN wget https://github.com/mozilla/geckodriver/releases/download/v0.14.0/geckodriver-v0.14.0-linux32.tar.gz
RUN tar xzf geckodriver-v0.14.0-linux32.tar.gz -C /usr/src/app/drivers
env PATH /usr/src/app/drivers:$PATH

CMD [ "python", "./app.py" ]
```

I get the error:
`selenium.common.exceptions.WebDriverException: Message: Expected browser binary location, but unable to find binary in default location, no 'moz:firefoxOptions.binary' capability provided, and no binary flag set on the command line`

The geckodriver is downloaded and added to tha PATH. When I try this on a native Win10 machine (w/o Docker) the app.py works. 

Are there some undocumented dependencies?

items.title: On windows splinter 0.7.5 installed selenium 3.0.1 but it seems that this selenium is not supported by splinter
